column2: 'Home Taping is killing music!'

Music producers and representatives of the recording industry have gathered today in $CAPITAL$ to meet with lawmakers to address a crisis in their sector: the growing amounts of bootleg recordings and home taping, reducing the sales of legal, copyrighted recordings.

Anti-copyright activists claim that there is no theft as the music was simply copied and shared for personal, non-commercial use, and most of those engaging in piracy would not have purchased it anyways. Thus, they should not be punished.

Both industry leaders and activists are hoping for an official government ruling on these issues in the coming days.
They are within their rights. Information wants to be free.
This is just a minor infringement on copyright laws.
Crack down on them. This is killing the music industry.
Piracy is theft, and we cannot tolerate lawbreakers.

'You wouldn't download a car!'

Anti-copyright activists claim that there is no theft as the digital files are simply downloaded and shared for personal, non-commercial use, and most of those engaging in piracy would not have purchased them anyways. Thus, they should not be punished.

Both industry leaders and activists are hoping for an official government ruling on these issues in the coming days.
They are within their rights. Information wants to be free.
This is just a minor infringement on copyright laws.

'You can click, but you can't hide!'

Software developers and representatives of several digital industries have gathered today in $CAPITAL$ to meet with lawmakers to address a crisis in their sector: the growing amounts software piracy and freebooting online, reducing the sales of legal, copyrighted materials.

Anti-copyright activists claim that there is no theft as the files and media were simply reuploaded and shared for personal, non-commercial use, and most of those engaging in piracy would not have purchased them anyways. Thus, they should not be punished.

Both industry leaders and activists are hoping for an official government ruling on these issues in the coming days.
They are within their rights. Information wants to be free.
This is just a minor infringement on copyright laws.

Piracy is theft, and we cannot tolerate lawbreakers.
'Virtual world crimes. Real life consequences!'

Anti-copyright activists claim that there is no theft as the vees were simply cloned and shared for personal, non-commercial use, and most of those engaging in piracy would not have purchased them anyways. Thus, they should not be punished.

Both industry leaders and activists are hoping for an official government ruling on these issues in the coming days.

'Be an integral person. Have your own personality!'

Neuroformers and representatives of the para-reality and hypercognitive industry have gathered today in $CAPITAL$ to meet with lawmakers to address a crisis in their sector: the growing amounts of 'liberated' personas and bootleg personality exponents, reducing the sales of legal, copyrighted personality modules.

Anti-copyright activists claim that there is no theft as the modules were simply cloned and implemented for personal, non-commercial use, and most of those engaging in piracy would not have purchased them anyways. Thus, they should not be punished.

Both industry leaders and activists are hoping for an official government ruling on these issues in the coming days.
